turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 231, Bill Hatahley et al, versus United States of America.
Mr. Marquis.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: May it please the Court.
Our position is two-fold.
First, we think the actions taken here were appropriate in enforcement of law regulating the grazing area of the public domain.

Second, we think that assuming that that is not so, assuming some defect is found in the procedures or a mistake as to the law applicable that that cannot be the basis of a judgment in the Tort Claims Act.
I don't think I need separately deal with the matter of the injunction.
I think so far as necessary, that will come out in the course of my discussion.
I think that the matter of damages is dealt with adequately in the briefs and I don't think that is necessary to be dealt upon during my argument.

First of all, and I think as the Court of Appeals held, we were plainly right, A, in applying the Utah abandoned horse law to the Taylor Grazing Act area and, B, in the procedures and so forth that were taken under that Act.
And I will have to leave to the briefs on the record the dealing with the details of that for the most part.
Now first, and this is the matter which is quite important in the administration of the Taylor Grazing Act.
It is the question, “Did the Taylor Grazing Act supersede the state law and in particular in this case, the state law as to abandoned horses?”
A three-minute summary of the situation when the Taylor Grazing Act was passed.
I don't think we need be reminded the importance of the public domain in the west to the livestock and cattle and sheep industries.
In the State of Utah, for example, 70% of the land is still public domain.

And that 70% -- the 30% that is privately or state owned is interspersed sections like school lands, 16s and 36s or the homesteads or small areas and the public domain runs through the entire area and it's a checkerboard.

For the most part, in this grazing area, the springs, the wells, the pass, the lowland where there's some cultivation, will be under a patent and the attached grazing area of wide scope will be public domain subject to grazing licenses.

Because of the very great importance of the grazing matter to the west, special laws had been built up special rules of law modifying the common law as to trespass and as to such matters in order to deal with the situation of an unfenced area of public domain of large importance to the local industry.
And of course, that is the source and has been the cause of dispute between cattle men and sheep men and had related in particular laws.
And of these, the abandoned horse law deals with a public health and public welfare problem.
It's the problem of abandoned -- is perhaps a misnomer in our eastern sense of someone abandoning their -- of their personal property like an automobile or something like that.
It's a matter of dealing with uncontrolled animals running loose on the unfenced public lands, the range of the west.
The problem is that there may be owners, there very likely is for all of them, but there has to be an enforced control of some sort dealing with the circumstances.
And we have to keep in mind the vast areas in the small population and the policing problem.

For example, San Juan County, Utah which is District Number 9 on the Taylor Grazing Act is 7800 square miles, somewhat larger than the State of Massachusetts, it's one of the largest counties in the country.
The particular area which I will come to in a minute where these eight Indian families claim the rights is of itself 760,000 acres, larger than the State of Rhode Island.
The population of San Juan County is roughly 5000.
These give a picture, of course, their vegetation is sparse so that there has to be large areas for grazing and we're dealing here with widely dispersed people and animals.

Now, this abandoned horse law and I might say that it is not peculiar to Utah, Wyoming and Montana, for example, have laws that are identical to the Utah law on this subject, set out a procedure whereby the menace and it's a menace to the existing animals on the range, the menace of mixed breeding and the animals running loose are likely to be the lower quality animals or those things the matter of horses running loose on the range is a menace.
It's a public house problem, public welfare problem, a public health problem to these areas in the west to which their grazing is so vital.
It's far beyond simply the forage that the horse may eat.
Well, that is a problem enough, all the dislocations caused by uncontrolled horses.
That is the particular program we're dealing with here.
And other programs, you look in the statutes of the western states, you look under livestock or animals, you will see a gradient quantity of legislation dealing with these problems.
Now, up until 1934, these western states had all enacted that legislation dealing with the public range which was most of the range, and the matter of the rights to graze had been governed by custom.
No special federal statute.
The Taylor --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Marquis, assume -- assuming that the authorities know who the owners of these animals are and assuming that they know that they are not really abandoned animals but are mere trespassers on the public domain, are they authorized by the state law to invoke the Abandoned Animal Act?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I would -- I would say, yes, to your question.
Of course, I -- I don't exactly agree with the assumptions.
But I would say, yes, to the statute.
The statute is dealing with the abandoned horses.

It is perfectly proper to invoke the statute which then simply puts on the burden of the animals the obligation to file a description of their animals and their brands and then there are measures for service by mail --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Could you quickly turn --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- and so forth.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- turn to the statute which you invoked, you can say yes to the Chief Justice's question?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: In the respondent's -- in the petitioner's brief, at page 58, the last page next to the cover.

“Any person owning any horses which are running at large in any county in which the Board of County Commissioners has given notice of intention to make a drive” as provided in this chapter, “may, within 30 days after posting or the first publication of the notice mentioned with the Board, file with the Board of County Commissioners a description of such horses claimed by him giving the marks and brands, if any, which appear thereof.
And if the Board of County Commissioners shall take into its possession any horses so-claimed, it shall, by registered level, address the owner or claimant of said horses, notify them and so forth.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, were those things done?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: There was no filing of description or brands in this case and hence there was no notice filed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then was the Act followed?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The Act was followed in the publication of that there will be a roundup.
There was not only publication in the newspaper, there was posting in the county seat, there was posting in five places outside the county seat.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why didn't they -- why didn't they follow the rest of the Act?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Because the rest of the Act does not come into play until in response to the fact that a roundup is -- occurs, then the owner files with the Board his description of his horses and his brands.
When he does that, then anytime any of those animals are seized, then the registered mail notice is given to the owner.
And that is --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In one of those acts, don't they make a distinction between abandoned horses and trespassers in which event they impound the horses and give notice and -- and enable the owners to get them back?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The impoundment law is a different law which is primarily directed at the herds of animals rather than the horses as such, but it would cover horses.
In that instance, it's the impoundment law.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Isn't that to be used -- isn't that to be used in cases where they either know who the owners are or have reasonable opportunity to know who the owners are?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I think that's the case where there's been continuing trespassing by abandoned sheep or abandoned cattle, someone grazing or something of that sort.
There has been continuous trespassing and a problem then they invoked the impoundment law.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Had there not been --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- continuous trespassing here?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: But -- that's right.
And this impoundment law, the local impoundment law, had been invoked by the white permittees who were entitled to own -- to graze the land.
And as the record will show, that is one of these episodes when the county sheriff was there enforcing the local impoundment law.
The abandoned horse law is something entirely different for a different purpose.
Its purpose is to rid the range of these uncontrolled animals running loose.
And the procedure there is to pick up the animals and when they know a roundup is coming, then the -- as I say, the owners file the descriptions and the brands.
And, for example, in this case, there were many horses running loose, there are as many as 400 horses running loose on the range.
The Indian horses were some of them.
It wasn't known to which Indians they belong of these eight families.
They were all running loose on the range and the notice was given in accordance with the statute that there would be a roundup of the horses.
And as might be expected when the notice was given, “We're going to have a roundup,” and they go out and they start looking at the range, most of the horses had disappeared.

I think that is perfectly in accord, first, getting back to what I was dealing with, I think it's perfectly in accord with the Taylor Grazing Act which preserve local police power and which preserve in its very first section of the Taylor Grazing Act.
It said that the jurisdiction of state courts -- of states is not to be affected except so far as necessarily.

On the top of page 69, at the end of Section 1, it starts on the very bottom of 68, the appendix of the Government's brief, “Nothing in this Act shall be construed in any way to diminish, restrict, or impair any right which is heretofore may hereafter initiated under existing law validly affecting the public lands and so forth.”
And then it comes down to about the fourth line, “Nor as limiting or restricting the power or authority of any state as to matters within its jurisdiction.”
My first point is therefore that the Taylor Grazing Act was not intended --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose that --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's a statement of an equivalent proposition, let me tell you that.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.
I think I want first to say that it -- I think that's clear that the Taylor Grazing Act was not intended to supersede all of the local law as to grazing matters.
That --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That it lets --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Then tell us what remains of the jurisdiction as to what the Taylor Grazing Act had so (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, I think -- again, we have one of those problems.
I think it leaves the local law except so far as there is conflict.
I think it makes it perfectly clear that section represents the policy and then there is the later section which is -- we didn't reprint it, it's in the petitioner's appendix.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there any definition in either the state or the federal law to what constitutes an abandoned animal?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: At page -- the petitioner's appendix.
At page 55, at the bottom, abandoned horses defined.

The term “abandoned horses” used in this chapter means any horse and other animals unbranded or if branded, that has escaped assessment for taxation for the year next preceding the killing of such animal as here and after provided for and running at large upon the open range of this state.
An animal not bearing a decipherable brand recorded in the Office of Recorder of Marks and Brands shall be deemed unbranded.”
It isn't put on knowledge at all, it's a question, I think it's quite reasonable in dealing with this partially settled area.

It puts -- it puts the burden on the owner in this area where animals are running loose to have his brand recorded and to -- when the roundup is announced, to file with the Board of Commissioners saying, “Well, now this is my animal.
If you pick it up, let me know about it.”
And then the statutory process proceeds from thereon.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Does the record show whether these animals escaped taxation the year before?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The record is completely silent about taxation.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They were branded, were they not?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: They were branded -- some of them were branded.
Some, there is dispute.
The Government's testimony was that they had looked in the brand books and could find no recorded brands.
There was testimony the finding is some of the brands were recorded.
How many isn't stated.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And the Government took those along with the unbranded.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: They're -- they were grouped.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They have a right to do that?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The Government, they will, I think.
Of course, it isn't the brand, it's the recording of the brand.
It isn't the brand on the animal when you're out on the range and picking up the horses.
It isn't the brand on the animal that makes the difference, it's the brand recorded in the book.
And of course they have brand books which our books contain the recorded brands and they have copies out on the range.
The testimony shows the government agents had the brand books with them.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well some of those you say were recorded brands?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The government agents say they could not find them in the books.
The Indian owners testified some were recorded.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What was the finding?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The finding was some were recorded brands.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: As to those that were recorded brands, what is your position as to whether the Government had the right to take them as abandoned animals?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I -- I say first, I think that the -- I don't think that the jurisdiction of the action under this statute is whether a particular animal was abandoned.
I don't think that is jurisdictional.
I think the statute places the obligation on the owner --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: To do what?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- to file his brand when the roundup is announced.
That was not done here.
I think that is the remedy that is provided.
It's the obligation which they put on persons quite reasonably because these animals are running loose on the vast range.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't follow.
I'm not --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- naturally not familiar with -- about these things, but if we accept the findings that some were branded, some of the brands were recorded, then I don't understand your last statement that there must be some -- when the roundup takes place, there must be some further filing.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I -- not -- but I think before the roundup takes place.
I think the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What's the purpose of having of the recording if that isn't to give notice for all purposes for which such a recording should be normally is called for?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, generally speaking, if it's a recorded brand, that gives the notice and that's your brand and it solves any problems of ownership, for instance, the record is prima facie evidence.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) -- that if you accept the finding --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that was true here to some in all of that, isn't it?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Accepting the finding, it was -- as some were recorded --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now you indicated --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- which ones --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that that's -- as you -- being asked by the Chief Justice a question, that doesn't take care of the fact that you shouldn't have --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, I think under the remedy, I think under the statute, the remedy provided if your recorded brand horse is picked up, the remedy is to file -- when a roundup is announced, to file your brand.
And if you do, then you do get notice if your recorded brand horse is picked up.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where is that from the statute?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's in the last part of the statute which I read.
That last page that if --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I see that's --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The section, it's at the top of page 58 of petitioner's brief that a person owning the horses which are running at large where there's been notice of intention.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: How -- how are the brands filed, by counties or by the State?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I'm not sure -- they're filed by counties, I believe it is.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well, if -- if they're filed -- is what you're saying that when a notice of a roundup is given of horses running loose, that then they must re-file their brand some place?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Notify the Board of County Commissioners, that's right.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: You mean after that -- after the notice that they're going to have a roundup?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: After the general notice of the roundup.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Even though they had already been filed in the county?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: And -- and where do you -- what do you draw of that?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: From the statute which says -- the page --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: I'm looking at page 58.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Page 58.

That the person, any person owning any horses which are running at large in which -- in the county where the Board has given notice and intention to make a drive, may, within 30 days after posting or first publication, file with the Board of County Commissioner a description --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: And how does the -- does the filing -- the finding show that they were -- some brands filed?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: There were none filed under this section.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: And therefore, your position is that none of the horses which were picked up were branded and filed in accordance with this Section 47-2 in this case?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right, in connection with that section and of course we do challenge the finding.
We say, of course, that the general finding about some of the brands being recorded.
And of course --

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: Where do you challenge it?
In what way do you challenge it?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: We say that --

turn.speaker: sherman_minton
turn.label: Justice Sherman Minton
turn.text: Well, I mean, on -- in Court, where did you -- did you present that to the Court of Appeals?
To the District Court?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Our challenge to the findings was not specific as to each particular finding.

We did challenge the findings as a whole and the ground on which inferences were drawn from the evidence on the ground that the basis of this alleged conspiracy between the federal officers and the local county sheriff and the local advisory board and all -- everyone else in the area was erroneous.
And that was the structure on which -- or the inferences and rejection of evidence was based.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Marquis, the finding that certain brands were recorded is about as rudimentary and elementary and simple and unambiguous to the finding of fact that one can conceive.
And therefore, the general objection to the inferences drawn, I should hardly think would cover such a finding that in a certain place, there's a piece of paper or books in which (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I -- of course there, we have the fact that it runs all through this case because the testimony was they looked in the book and it wasn't there.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I'm not saying you shouldn't have challenged it, I'm suggesting that your answer to Justice Minton's question, you attack the structure of the conclusive report was hardly the type of question of an entry in a book.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, perhaps, our statement of points on appeal was not detailed enough.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that doesn't mean by not certainly defined is --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: [Laughs] -- I -- they are certainly detailed find -- statement of points and we didn't attempt to go through all each individual finding in each individual element because in our view --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But is important --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- it all represented a single -- of course, in first on the law, we think it makes no difference.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right, I understand that.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: And secondly --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) get it approved, then it does become important.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: And secondly, we think that the answer is, the answer throughout the case and the thing that dispels all the findings of that sort where evidence has been expressly rejected, the thing that cuts across all of that is the charge of the plot or malicious scheme to oust these Indians from an area where they undoubtedly had rights.
That is the theory on which all that flows throughout the case.

And we expressly attack that because of the fact that Congress had, I think, quite clearly indicated that these Indians should remain in their view upon the reservation and I think it's perfectly clear that as the state court held on this precise question, that for at least three reasons as a matter of law, the Indians had no rights in this area to graze, they were trespassers, that they be -- these six families belong on the reservation with the rest of the Indians who had been in this general area.
And as long as I'm on that, I'd like to just in five minutes to --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could I -- before you do that --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Sure.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- could I clarify my mind on one point.
Was there any finding one way or the other as to whether or not the brands were filed with the County Commissioners as distinguished and having been recorded?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I don't think there was a specific finding.
The evidence is perfectly clear that there was –-

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: There is a dispute that they were not --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: There were no -- there was no filing at all with the County Commissioner.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: None.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That fact is clear.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And your claim is, as I understand it, even though the evidence was or the finding was that some brands are recorded, that in itself was not enough absent a filing of those recorded brands with the County Commissioner.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: After a roundup --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: After a roundup of --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- of -- of horses running wild has been announced, that's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. -- oh, pardon me.
Go ahead.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Are you going to discuss the Federal Range Code?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I will in just a moment.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Because the major point in the case would be that is in conflict --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, well I --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: -- governing trespassers or violators in Federal Range -- the General Range Code governing trespassers and violators.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, I propose to get to that just in a moment, if I may.
I would like -- well, I can deal with that subject right now, it follows logically enough.
The point is -- our point is that this abandoned horse law is not a trespass law.
It is not a law for -- to get the individual who has been trespassing with his band of sheep or his band of cattle, who has been running beyond the area where he is permitted.
Of course, the Taylor Grazing Act sets up a system of permits.
It regularizes the matter which before it --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: The person who doesn't have a permit from the Taylor Grazing Act but grazes his cattle or livestock is a violator, isn't it?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: He is violating the Taylor Grazing Act.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Do you come under the --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: So -- so --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: -- Federal Range Code?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.

He is violating the Federal Range Act -- the Taylor Grazing Act and the regulations set up a procedure for giving trespass notices, that's what they're always called in vernacular, it's a trespass notice, for those that are grazing their sheep or cattle either beyond the period of their permit or beyond the time during the year when it's permitted or too many sheep or too many cattle or many of those various reasons, it's almost invariably.

Some basis on which they're on the range on the permits of -- their exceeding a permit usually, but any sort of trespass of the cattle or the sheep by an owner is dealt with in the matter of procedure under the Federal Range Code in which notice is given and trespass action is taken either through the United States Attorney or the regulations provide invocation of local law of impoundment for trespassers which, for instance, in Utah law is covered by estrays.
All of that we say --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: This is -- this is a 161 Level, is that what you're talking about?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You could've proceeded under that, could you?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Not on this abandoned horse -- in our view of what the situation is, that it's abandoned horses.
That procedure is against named and known owners.
You -- you name him, you've been trespassing with your band of sheep here on Section 17 in Township 39, something of that sort.
This roundup is a matter of rounding up the stray animals running all over, the uncontrolled animals on the public range.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well these --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: There were 400 when we started.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, this -- wasn't there a finding in this case that to the effect that the government agents waited at the night time until these horses were turned out of the corrals and then rounded them up?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: There was one instance.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, there was a finding to that effect, wasn't there?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: As to that one instance.
That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.
Now as to those, do you claim that those are abandoned animals as distinguished from trespassing animals?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: We -- in our version of facts, we do, yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What is the difference between the trespass and the -- and the abandonment so far as this situation is concerned?
How do you -- how do you say it's one and not the other?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The abandoned animals are simply running loose and uncontrolled whereas trespass is a band under almost invariably under control of a herder of a band or may it could be a band of horses ordinarily as cattle or sheep which are under control and therein a place where they're not authorized to be.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, where do you get that definition, or those two definitions?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The definition of abandoned horse, of course, I get from the Utah definition of the statutory definition.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, where do you get the trespassing one?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, that's -- that isn't specifically given in any -- I don't know of any place where it is specifically set forth.
I mean, in that sense, of course, it is trespass, any -- in the sense, the trespass is where some -- an animal at a place where it shouldn't be.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And is it -- is it --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Isn't that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- the policy of the Government in -- in these matters generally speaking, to consider a horse that is corralled normally but is permitted to be outside at night trespassing on the domain being it an abandoned animal?
Is that the policy?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I don't know of any policy on that at all, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- presume not.
I don't know.
I just don't know.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You -- you would presume it was not to be?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, that's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That -- that's --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I presume that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What that -- that was done here, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, according to the findings, of course, our version is entirely different.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then I suppose that the general policy was in accordance with the general definitions, was it not?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Oh, yes.
That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then why do you change the definition and the policy in this case?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I don't -- I'm sorry, I don't follow you.
I don't understand (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, as I -- as I understood you, normally, if an animal was a corralled animal and was merely let loose at night to forage known to the government agents, that that horse would be considered a trespasser and not an abandoned animal.

But in this case, you reversed it and although there is a finding in the case to the effect that the government agents were there and watched until the horses were permitted to go outside of their corrals and then scooped them up as abandoned animals.
That they're no longer to be considered merely as trespassing animals.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, as I say, as to that particular episode, I don't know there's any general policy has been set up on things like that and we do not agree that that is what happened.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, didn't the --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Of course.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- trial court found that, didn't it?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, it did.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And didn't --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, it did.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did they find it on the -- on the evidence of your own government agents?
Did your --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- government agents testified that there were --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: No, sir.
The Government agents were that it was quite -- quite a considerable distance away.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That the government agents were that these horses were quite a considerable distance away and could --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Didn't they go farther than that?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: And could not be under the view of being within control.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, didn't they --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That they weren't simply within the mediate area of the corral.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But didn't your government agents admit in the trial that they knew they had been released from the corral that night?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I don't believe so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I may --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: As to that, if so --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I may be mistaken.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I don't think so.
No, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I may be mistaken to that.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: But as to that particular episode, that is our view of it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, may I know (Inaudible) in that episode?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: In that particular episode, I believe there were -- I think that altogether, they were 20.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where is that testimony in the record, do you know?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: At page 181 is the testimony of the Indian, of Sakezzie, the Indian owner.
That's the testimony about it.
The --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: 125 (Inaudible) 128.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: And then at the bottom of 130 -- 128 it begins, “In a moonlight night, and sat up on the top of -- above overlooking Sakezzie's corral and so forth.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But is this -- is this the agent?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: This is the government agent.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The government agent.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The answer, it was more than that.
On page 128 --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- of the record it begins.
It was more than that.
How much more?
Out on the mesa on federal range.
You watched them move from the corral out there where you picked them up?
I did not.
You had a pickup there, didn't you -- a pickup car there, didn't you?
I was on Alkali Point 15 or 20 miles from the area where the horses were picked up.
Were you the only man driving that pickup truck that night?
No.
Who else was driving?
Bob Crum.
Later on he testifies very briefly.
Didn't you know they were coming out of his corral?
I didn't know they came out of his corral.
It was dark when he turned them out.
I can't identify any of those horses in the corral.
Then where did you take them when you picked them up?
And it goes on from there.
That's the government agents' evidence on the subject.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Apparently the District Court didn't believe that.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I wouldn't either.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How many horses are involved in the whole accident?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: There are 115 horses and 38 burros, I believe it is.
The -- I won't go into the details.
We think that -- I think we've pretty well covered it that our view that the Utah abandoned horse law was properly applied under the Utah procedure and the purposes of the statute.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Suppose the man in turning up his horses might (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, I -- I think so.
I think it depends on a degree of how close or how far they were in all said circumstances as that, I wouldn't suppose.
That, of course, is simply one instance.
I -- I would like to deal very briefly with this matter of the title.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, before you get to the -- before you get to the title, the -- the Federal Range Law requires the Government to give notice to the owners when it knows who the owners of the horses are, does it not?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: To the name -- to named owners, when he knows that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
That notice must be in writing.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did you give -- did they give such notice?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Not as to these -- at this time, no, sir.

Of course, the -- as to trespass, as the Government's position that the -- these eight families has no right on the land, on this range, that had been given earlier in connection with the Hosteen case which have been brought --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That had nothing to do with this procedure --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Which had been --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- for destroying these animals.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: It had nothing to do with the procedure and our view is that that simply does not apply to the abandoned horse roundup procedure which has been used several times in Utah in the grazing districts and have been in the administrative view.
But that is the proper way to get rid of the animals.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Who -- who made the determination to use the abandoned horse plan?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Does the record show that?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes.
There's some testimony here on the part of the operative decision that invoked it now, was by Mr. Kinneman who is the range manager in this area.
It was done with the knowledge --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Is he the -- the highest authority in the operation of this range?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, in the -- in the --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: In the area?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, in the particular area and it was done with knowledge of his superior as to enforcement of it's -- by -- the overall operator is the immediate superior of Kinneman, the range manager of this district and the adjoining district.
His superior by name of Newman is the general area -- of the grazing area had agreed to --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Now, do -- does the record show directions to proceed under this abandoned horse?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: It shows that they had invoked it in the past and that he agreed to invoke it this time.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: And that this -- this man in charge of the roundup was instructed to proceed in that way?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Was instructed to invoke the abandoned horse law of Utah in this grazing district.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Are you going to discuss whether or not that creates a liability assuming that they improperly invoked it?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, I am.
I would like to come to that right now in response to Your Honors' question.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Before you do that, may I ask you one question to follow up the horses that -- that you were talking about, when the Chief asked you about whether they were --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- corralled, the Court found that they watched them and then picked them up?
What happened to those particular horses?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: They were corralled.
The -- for approximately two weeks, I believe that some of those were sold to local operators the -- generally speaking.
And of course, this process went on from September 19 until the following February.
It wasn't an instantaneous process that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are these particular (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- we think of roundup.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I gather --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: These --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- from what you said afterwards, they -- was -- was some of them shot?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I don't believe any of this particular group was shot because of -- the ones that were shot were on the range and being transported and primarily they were -- that occurred in February.
I don't believe any of this particular group were shot --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But they took these particular horses --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- on the range.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- onto a corral, isn't it?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: They were taken to a corral.
They stayed there for about two weeks.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Who kept them there?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The government agents.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The government agents.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: In the corral.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And how -- then what did they do with them?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Then --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How did they dispose of them?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I don't remember these particular ones.
Some of them were sold.
A great many --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What was the authority --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- of them --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- for selling?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: This abandoned horse law of Utah.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In other words, the government agents picked them up on the public lands.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: On the public lands.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Herd them to a corral.
Who ran that corral, the Government?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, I believe so.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The Government's corral.
And then they sold them?
Were they all sold?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: No.
Some of them were sold of the group and I don't -- as I say, I don't remember which precisely was done with these particular ones.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: At what point did the Government officers begin to act under the state law?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The entire procedure was under the state law.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean when they --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's the -- that's the procedure for -- under the abandoned horse law.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When they -- when the government agents picked them up on the --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: They were going out --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- public land.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- and conducting a roundup under --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As part of the State?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- the abandoned -- abandoned horse law.
That's --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As part of the State?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And they could have disposed of them under the federal law, could they then?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: No.
The federal law has no similar procedure.
The federal law is a trespass law.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm -- I'm talking about that precise procedure, but did the federal law provide a method for taking care of horses like that when -- that they caught?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: No, I don't think the federal law provides for anything except trespass --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, were -- but there were --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- notices and then a trespass -- then a lawsuit.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They were trespassers, right?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They were trespassers (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The -- the federal law has no expressed provision for impoundment of the animals.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the federal law --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- does provide a remedy for the Government, under which the government officials can act disposing of horses seized precisely as these were.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: It does not provide for seizure --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But what -- what is it --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- or impoundment.

The federal law does not provide for seizure or impoundment except that the Secretary's regulations do expressly provide that local impoundment law may be followed or an action brought in the Federal District Court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Then it's your position -- it's your position that no disposition could be made of these horses by the Government under the Taylor Grazing Act or any regulation passed pursuant to it unless they went through the state law?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That the abandoned horse law, that that was the procedure to follow and that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And that there was no other procedure that could be followed?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: As to these -- as to animals or disposing of animals, that's right.
There's no federal procedure.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They couldn't proceed any other -- make any other procedure for seizing them at all or protecting the Government's interest from those trespassing animals?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: There's no -- there's no federal procedure at all except the lawsuit against the individual owner.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it does --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: There is nothing for impoundment or seizure of the animals that are doing the trespassing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes, I understand.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that the part of the settling at the end of Article 1 of the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I think that, of course, the legislative history is sound.
My view is that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That -- that sort --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That that sort of thing was left to the states and it -- has existent before the Taylor Grazing Act was passed.
And that that's the sort of thing that was not intended --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Under the Taylor Grazing --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- to be --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- Act, is there a general provision for the rules and regulations by the --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- Grazing Act?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes.
There is a usual provision -- that the rule --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- the Secretary may make rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of the Act.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is it -- is it your view that that single authorization wouldn't enable the department to make use of the regulation?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, he has in his regulation what he has done and I think perfectly properly.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I'm -- I'm (Inaudible) does Section 161.11 which provides for the -- that (a) provides the notice to the alleged violator, is that right?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Then 161.11 (b) provides for impoundment under local law if there has been found to be a violation here.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That -- that's right.
That's right.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The owner --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You can under federal law round them up.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: It is the Secretary's regulation.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The Secretary's regulation refers to --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Well, that's the part --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- local law.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right, that --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But you said -- you said under federal law you can't do it.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, as I say --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Under this provision of 161.11, you'd end up impounding under local law if you follow the --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That -- that's --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: -- the local procedure.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, that's the point I was getting at.
The claim here is that that part of the statute, that part of the regulation is invalid because --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But you didn't proceed (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- because federal law occupies the whole field.
My answer is that that regulation is valid in incorporating that local impoundment law as the procedure.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But that invokes local law only at the end of a -- of a federal procedure.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: And here, this federal procedure wasn't invoked at all.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.
And my view is that that particular -- it shows that the federal statute didn't occupy the complete field.
That it's still left operative, this particular abandoned horse rule.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where do we find the provision for a written notice in the federal -- federal code to the owners?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: It's in -- first of all, in this Taylor Grazing Act itself, and that's on page 52 --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- of the petitioner's appendix.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The general provision, any local violation of the provisions of this Act or of such rules and regulations thereunder, after actual notice thereof shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $500.
That's the statute.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Then on page 54, this is the Secretary's regulations --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- which it --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Which is the law?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Whenever it appears that there has been any willful violation, the range manager will cause the alleged violator and then the interest of landholder who has filed notice of his land to be served with a written notice which will set forth the act or acts constituting such violation and so forth.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.
Was there a violation here?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: There -- as -- yes, I would think there's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: -- also a violation.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was -- was there a written notice?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Not at this instance, no, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Because in our view, it's impossible to give written notice of an abandoned horse situation.
And that in --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Even when they're branded and registered?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, because they're running uncontrolled on the range.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.
But you had them -- and they had a brand.
They were branded and the Court's finding wouldn't have (Inaudible) registered for that.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Some of them were recorded.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, some of them.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So why don't that be (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.
The most we -- the most we know is it simply belonged to one of the seven families of Indians.
They were Indian horses ranging over this vast area of 700,000 acres.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Some were in various places over.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, the Court found they -- they only ranged from the corral to the truck of your government agents, isn't it?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Well, these were various spots located throughout these vast area of the -- of this range.
That particular episode was in one place and the other instances were other areas throughout this vast area.

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: And I don't know how you could --

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: -- finding of the Court on page 36 with reference to these animals that came out of the corral at night and were rounded up by the government agents, doesn't take it to another corral.
The Indians follow them and ask for their animals back.
And the agents proceeded to get some guns and load them in their presence and scare them away.
Isn't it?
Isn't that what happened?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.
That was their story.

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: Did that happen?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: The version which we have is entirely different.

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: But the Court had evidence for this version.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.
There was some evidence of that version.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, did you dispute this finding in the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Not in terms of this direct finding.
No, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are you -- are you in a position to dispute it here?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: We -- our -- our view is that the situation, the conduct of the case and in view of all the evidence.
The view taken is so founded throughout the case upon this notion that there was a conspiracy and that that is the ground on which so much evidence is rejected and put out of mind.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was there a finding that there was a conspiracy?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Throughout the case, there is this reference, the plot, the plan --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Who was (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: A, the federal officers, range officers in the area.
B, actors in this -- in some of the episodes here were the Sheriff and Deputy Sheriff of San Juan County, Utah.

C, the Board of Commissioners of San Juan County, Utah, two of them testified and the Secretary of the Board testified and their testimony was rejected in part on the ground that it was all part of this conspiracy.
Next, the Advisory Board under the Taylor Grazing Act, which provides for a local advisory board to advise the local managers on operation and enforcement of the Taylor Grazing Act.
And finally, the white grazers who had permits to operate on this land and had been the plaintiffs in the state court circuit.

We say the answer -- and that flows through the entire picture of the case that you can pick out and view one or the other of these matters because of the view of the -- that that exist -- that plot or scheme was existed.
And we say that is simply not so because of one primary fact.

The assumption of all that matter of plot or conspiracy is that the federal officers and the local officers were attempting to oust these Indians from the area without giving them a chance to litigate their alleged rights.

Now, the fact is that I think the statute, it's very unusual, Congress had said in creating the extension of the reservation right next door to this area and most of the Indians had moved into the Aneth Extension in 1933 when it was created.
Congress had gone to unusual lengths in saying that there shall not be lapping over on to adjacent area.
And it had said that con -- it had provided contrary to usual law that no further allotments to lands to Indians on the public domain shall be made in San Juan County, Utah.
And it had provided that the Indian Homestead Act of 1884 which gives Indians a right to obtain homesteads without charge on public domain should not apply to San Juan County, Utah.

That it -- very clearly limited the Indian, the Navajo Indians to the Aneth Extension and to the Navajo reservation, that that is the view that has been taken throughout by the Government, that that was expressly passed on by the local county court of San Juan County and then the state court -- Supreme Court of San Juan County, Utah in a decision that is clearly correct and that the fallacy all the way through here is simply ignoring the existence of that fact.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, Mr. Marquis --

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- do you contend that there is no evidence in the record from which the trial court could have found that there was any said scheme or plan or conspiracy, if you choose to call it such, on the part of these people or any of them?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I -- I certainly affirmably say there was -- there is no evidence of the plot because it couldn't have existed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why didn't you raise that then in the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: We did precisely raise that.
And that's our view which was -- it so undercut all the findings that it was inappropriate to go into details.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, what -- what is the challenge which brings out to sustain your answer that it did challenge that?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I'm -- at page 3 --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: At page 3 of the record, about the middle of the page, number 14 as to conduct of trial and damages.
This is all under the heading, the Court -- District Court erred.

“In finding, without basis in the evidence or reasonable inference from the evidence, that it was the motive of the agents and employees of the United States both alone and in concert with white livestock operators to harass and molest the Indians and to kill their animals so that they would be compelled to leave the range and could no longer assert a right to use the area in question.”
That question was precisely raised.
The Court of Appeals like -- found it unnecessary to go into it because the basic findings, the basic facts are there.
We think it perfectly clear and up until now, I should say this, at page 84 of the record, the very beginning of the trial, I think it shows what's happened.

And in their reply brief, the petitioners in this Court quote certain excerpts along with that part, but the very -- those two sentences that they leave out where the Court is talking about alleged violation of its order and it's going to issue a temporary restraining order, he's talking about injunction.
Mr. Thomas, the Assistant United States Attorney, I wonder if it not might been -- it might not be my duty at this time to call attention to the decision of the Supreme Court of Utah.
The agent had previously said, “Well, I thought I knew the status, I was relying on that case.”
Of course, the case had been decided by the Supreme Court of Utah.
It held that these Indians were trespassers.
The fact is that one of these episodes which is described in the finding, the episode of the handcuffing of the Indian women, the finding doesn't mention it.
The man who put the handcuffs on was the local county sheriff of San Juan County, Utah acting under the state impoundment law.

We say that that is typical of this whole case that the fact is that as Congress had made so clear and as the Supreme Court of Utah had held expressly dealing with these subjects that the Indians were not entitled, this group of six families were not entitled to graze upon this area that they were obliged, they should go to the reservation and remain there.
That the issuance of licenses on the Taylor Grazing Act to the white grazers was perfectly valid and that they had the rights in the area.

And up till now until yesterday in the argument where it was said the decision was wrong, throughout the record in this case in the District Court, throughout the briefs in this Court, there has never been any indication of what is the answer to that state court proceeding which had been the Supreme Court of Utah had decided this case and held the Indians had the right prior to any of these events in May of 1952 and these were events occurred along in the summer of 1952.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Isn't the real nub of this controversy, whether or not the Utah Abandoned Horse Law applies and if it applies whether its provisions were followed?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: If it applies and its provisions were followed, then it doesn't make any difference, does it, whether the motive was to oust these Indians?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I don't think so.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Now, what do you say to the reverse of that?
If the abandoned horse law does not apply or was not a problem, what's your position then as far as liability is concerned?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I -- I think if the abandoned horse law does not apply, then we are faced with the Tort Claims problem.
Is it within -- is A, let us say, the -- I think there's three situations.
A -- a decision was that erroneous, that Utah law applied in all, whereas the Taylor Grazing Act, that it imply -- apply to the entire field.

It seems to be perfectly clearly if that is the ground, it's the wrong, the tort that occurred, that is within -- is at that level, it's a decision of what rule applies and is within the scope of the discretionary function, et cetera.
If it's a matter of the details of application of the Utah law, if a mistake or wrong was committed there some place, it seems --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible) may I interrupt to say that the motive may be important on you're A, namely, it's one thing to make an honest mistake as to state law and another case, they have a purposeful desire to (Inaudible) the right that are outside of the case.

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: I -- that -- that is the ground and also credibility is the ground on which it got into this case, I think, this title issue.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Supposed it -- suppose you assume that there was a conspiracy to oust the Indians and to get the conspiracy charge to oust the Indians to get the range.
Was that within the scope of the employment of the government officials?

turn.speaker: roger_p_marquis
turn.label: Mr. Roger P. Marquis
turn.text: It certainly seems to me that you're faced with two things then.
Either you're outside of the scope of the government official which is not -- certainly it's not within the expectable range of employment to engage in a conspiracy of that sort.
